title: Visual Thinking
long_description: Visual thinkers can teach with imagery. They use photographic tools to capture student work and bring it to the screen. They help students become visually literate by using cameras, drawing tools and a thought process.

challenges.title: Capture images of students at work
challenges.short_description: Students draw, use manipulatives or act out. You capture their thinking with photos. Use the photos to start discussions or build new lessson.

challenges.title: Use a photo shoot to teach a concept
challenges.short_description: Challenge students to stage their ideas and capture them in photos. Think of storytelling, glossaries or anything else that can be captured with actors and a camera.

challenges.title: Create a comic book with your students
challenges.short_description: Creating a comic book entails taking a story apart into key actions and ordering them in a sequence. These are crucial literacy skills which grow much easier when kids are creating comic books.

challenges.title: Use a mind-mapping tool in your teaching
challenges.short_description: Mind maps show thinking, connections and structure. Model this way of thinking for students by using a mind-mapping tool with your students' help. This is a great beginning to any jigsaw activity.

challenges.title: Teach kids to deconstruct an image
challenges.short_description: A single image can trigger a lot of insights and questions. In a media-saturated world, students need to understand how images portray the world.

challenges.title: Explore Google Earth
challenges.short_description: Google Earth puts an interactive globe on your whiteboard. You can explore at any level of detail, and find images and notes on the places you study. Student can use Google Earth in our computer lab.

challenges.title: Create a story sequence with images
challenges.short_description: Find a series of images that either tell a story or could tell a story with students' help. The right series of images invites a variety of responses.

challenges.title: Teach kids to organize visually
challenges.short_description: Kids will often have an easier time remembering what they've found out if they can make a visual record. Using digital tools means they can share their work and use it as a jumping off point.
